content: #全民慢病健康科普计划#这个话题都没什么专家科普long covid这种新的慢病。这就对比出差距，Ｘ上直接学术讨论。

How the liberal arts can save higher educationComputerized, job-focused learning undercuts the true value of higher education. Liberal arts should be our model for the future.liberal artsCredit: Igor / Adobe StockKEY TAKEAWAYSEducrats, ideologues, and politicians argue that the liberal arts are impractical and that higher education should aim to make students “job-ready day one.” This assault on the liberal arts has led to enrollments in the humanities to plummet. However, the liberal arts help students build the soft skills employers desire, the connections to help them grow, and the inquisitiveness to lead a prosperous life.Loading your audio articleGayle GreeneCopy a link to the article entitled http://How%20the%20liberal%20arts%20can%20save%20higher%20educationShare How the liberal arts can save higher education on FacebookShare How the liberal arts can save higher education on Twitter (X)Share How the liberal arts can save higher education on LinkedInExcerpted from Immeasurable Outcomes: Teaching Shakespeare in the Age of the Algorithm by Gayle Greene. Copyright 2023. Published with permission of Johns Hopkins University Press.One of the shocking things I discovered, writing this book, is how much of what we read and hear about education is simply not true. Mainstream media turn to business leaders, politicians, tech moguls, for “expert” opinions. They’re more likely to accept a press release from a billionaire-funded think tank or foundation than ask an educator, so they perpetuate the narrative of higher education as a “broken fiscal model” that needs to be transformed, to be made more like business.FEATURED VIDEOSLoneliness: The silent killer, and how to beat it | Richard Reeves & more01:4823:50They feature attention-grabbing stories of admissions scandals, athletic scandals, snowflake students, “cancel” culture — “if it bleeds, it leads” — stories that highlight what’s wrong with higher education, but have little relevance to the experience of most undergraduates. The media give disrupters inordinate air time. Kevin Carey, author of The End of College, and Ryan Craig, author of College Disrupted, advocate doing away with “bricks and mortar” colleges and “unbundling” higher education into online learning and workplace-directed programs. For them, as for [Bill] Gates, the “value” of higher education is measurable and monetary, training that yields maximum return on investment.Society has ceased believing in a liberal education, and educators are losing heart. Higher education has allowed itself to be defined by educrats, ideologues, politicians who would have us produce workers “job-ready on day one,” in the words of former President Barack Obama, whose Education Department was packed with Gates Foundation people. We in the liberal arts watch as enrollments plummet and humanities courses and programs are replaced by degree programs with “product-market fit,” as the Charles Koch Foundation advocates. The assault on the liberal arts is bipartisan, one of the few things Democrats and Republicans can get together on; and it’s been extremely effective.Students are flocking to majors in STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) because they’ve been told this is where the jobs are — when in fact, there are more STEM graduates than there are jobs. They’ve been told the humanities offer poor job prospects — when, as Karl Voss explains in the Hechinger Report, “Employers consistently say that they are looking for employees who can analyze complex, multifaceted problems, are creative and innovative, have good communication skills, are willing to learn, work … with a variety of people, see the larger setting in which decisions are made, and understand the ethical dimension of decisions and interactions” — all of which the liberal arts develop. “The difference between humanities majors and science majors, in median income and unemployment, seems to be no more than the difference between residents of Virginia and North Carolina,” writes Benjamin Schmidt in the Atlantic: “If someone told to me not to move to Charlotte because no one there can make a living, I would never take them seriously.”“Death Spiral,” “Budget Bloodbath,” “Extinction-Level Event” are familiar headlines for what is happening to the humanities. And it’s not only the liberal arts, but higher education itself on the chopping block, denounced as “unsustainable,” student debt exceeding credit card debt — “the public won’t take it anymore,” “the bubble’s about to burst,” an avalanche is coming our way, a tsunami is about to hit. A tsunami did hit, in the spring of 2020, though not in a form anyone anticipated: Less than a year after the onset of COVID-19, by February 2021, U.S. colleges and universities saw their workforce cut by 13%. Administrators leap at the promises of ed tech to deliver a future of online teaching, though now that we’ve had a taste of how alienating and ineffective this can be, most students and faculty appreciate more than ever the value of person-to-person teaching.“Death Spiral,” “Budget Bloodbath,” “Extinction-Level Event” are familiar headlines for what is happening to the humanities.Gayle Greene“Personalized learning” is what Gates calls computerized programs that have kids sitting at screens, following the prompts of an algorithm. He devises tech-heavy, standardized, test-driven programs for other people’s children, while sending his own to the posh, private school he attended himself, Lakeside: “I had great relationships with my teachers. … Classes were small. You got to know the teachers. They got to know you. And the relationships that come from that really make a difference. If you like and respect your teacher, you’re going to work harder.” Gates knows what works. Everyone knows what works: small classes where teachers can give students individual attention. Teaching and learning are things done with people, by people, for people, dependent on the trust and goodwill, presence, participation, responsiveness of human beings.“If there is one thing that the educational research clearly and consistently demonstrates, it is that the most successful long-term results for students occur when they are able to develop close relationships with their faculty,” writes Joshua Kim, director of Digital Learning Initiatives at Dartmouth Center for the Advancement of Learning. When asked, “Is there innovation/idea/movement methodology that excites you in terms of the future of education?” he advises, “Get a liberal arts education.” If we hope to “reimagine and revolutionize education,” we should recognize that “the most powerful personalized and adaptive learning platform ever invented is an experienced and well-supported educator”: “Give me an oval table, an experienced and well-supported educator, and 12 curious students — and I’ll rip out every single piece of campus technology.” Strong words, from a techie, but research corroborates that relationships are “central to a successful college experience,” as Daniel Chambliss and Christopher Takacs conclude on the basis of a 10-year study of students and alums of Hamilton College, a small liberal arts college in New York. Relationships matter more than the technology being sold to schools and colleges in the name of “innovation,” more than the subjects studied. They matter especially to first-generation students and students of color, and they matter especially now, when students have been starved of human connection for too long. They matter in terms of “long-term life outcomes,” as Richard Detweiler concluded on the basis of a study of 1,000 graduates of all kinds of colleges, “by  educating people for lives of consequence, inquiry, and accomplishment,” accomplishments that serve not only the individual but “the common good.”

content: 我自己的感觉是，阳完一年之内的心肺功能都没有恢复到先前的水平，而且确实有脑雾之类的long-covid现象。周围问了一圈下来，得到的反馈都是不管病程长短以及汹涌与否，发病期也就是难受那几天，对健康的成年人来说不算是最难熬的（可能得一次流感也差不多的症状），这之后漫长的疲惫恢复期才是真正考验人的身心

在新冠疫情中和长新冠（Long COVID/PASC）研究中做出了卓越贡献（微博正文）的St Louis VA在今天上线的Nature Med上发表了一项十分重要的长新冠队列研究，报道了感染SARS-CoV-2后随访3年患者发生PASC的情况。在感染SARS-CoV-2后的非住院患者中，在感染SARS-CoV-2一年后，患者全因死亡风险并未增加，但SARS-CoV-2感染后造成长新冠从而影响工作、生活（DALYs）发生率为9.6/1000人。在感染SARS-CoV-2后的住院患者中，感染后第3年患者死亡风险增加1.29%，但DALYs发生率为90/1000人。这项研究提示，随着时间推移，SARS-CoV-2感染者全因死亡风险显著下降；但住院患者依然存在DALYs风险。#长新冠#

新文章：英国病理学家认定，一名 36 岁的母亲很可能在接种第一剂辉瑞 COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗 11 天后死亡为什么全球疫苗接种三年后仍未对疫苗受害者进行适当的尸检英国病理学家认定 36 岁的 Dawn Wooldridge 很可能在接种第一剂辉瑞 COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗 11 天后死亡“去年 (2021) 6 月，伍尔德里奇女士因未能接五岁儿子放学而被其哥哥发现在家中死亡。”她的家人，包括她的丈夫、她的兄弟和他的妻子，以及她的继父母都参加了雷丁的调查他们听说她去世那天一切正常——早上送儿子去学校，和朋友喝咖啡，下午还和母亲通了电话。验尸官表示，伍尔德里奇女士的医疗记录证实她于 6 月 4 日接种了第一剂 Covid-19 疫苗。病理学家苏克温德·加陶拉 (Sukhvinder Ghataura) 告诉验尸官，她死亡时身体状况良好，毒理学报告也没有发现她体内有酒精或毒品的迹象。唯一值得注意的问题是心脏发炎、肺部积液以及肺部有一小块血块。病理学家认为，这些症状，加上接种疫苗后的几天内出现的月经不调和下巴和手臂疼痛，都与心肌炎（心脏炎症）有关。“他告诉验尸官：”从可能性上看，她有与疫苗相关的问题。我没有其他理由可以解释。在我看来，这是最可能的原因。唐恩很可能死于对新冠疫苗的反应。“向这位勇敢的病理学家致敬，他的勇气比所有加拿大和澳大利亚医生的勇气加起来还要大(I我总说推动接种疫苗的加拿大医生是世界上最糟糕、最无能的，澳大利亚医生紧随其后！)。但我们确实有办法确定 COVID-19 疫苗是否导致死亡。这叫做免疫组织化学。你可以对组织进行 COVID-19 核衣壳蛋白和刺突蛋白染色。摘自 Michael Palmer 博士和 Sucharit Bhakdi 博士的论文：“感染病毒的细胞会表达所有病毒蛋白，包括刺突蛋白和核衣壳。相比之下，基于 mRNA 的 COVID 疫苗只会诱导刺突蛋白的表达”摘自 Michael Morz 于 2022 年 10 月撰写的论文“一名 76 岁帕金森病患者在接种第三剂新冠疫苗三周后死亡……死者家属要求进行尸检”“对 SARS-CoV-2 抗原（刺突蛋白和核衣壳蛋白）进行了免疫组织化学研究。”“令人惊讶的是，在大脑和心脏的炎症病灶内，特别是在小血管的内皮细胞中，只能检测到刺突蛋白，而没有检测到核衣壳蛋白。由于没有检测到核衣壳蛋白，因此刺突蛋白的存在必须归因于疫苗接种，而不是病毒感染。”美国、加拿大、澳大利亚、新西兰或英国在尸检过程中均未进行 SARS-CoV-2 抗原的免疫组织化学检测。为什么？因为医疗当局知道，大多数突然和不明原因的死亡是由 COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗引起的，而不是长期 COVID。他们受制药巨头的委托，不惜一切代价保护价值 2000 多亿美元的 mRNA 产业。这就是为什么 mRNA 工厂继续在世界各地建造。无论有多少人死亡，它们都没有停止的打算。NEW ARTICLE: UK Pathologist rules 36 year old mom most likely died from Pfizer COVID-19 mRNA Vaccine 11 days after her 1st doseWhy proper autopsies of Vaccine victims are STILL not being done 3 years into global vaccinationUK Pathologist rules 36 yo Dawn Wooldridge most likely died from Pfizer COVID-19 mRNA Vaccine 11 days after her 1st dose"Ms Wooldridge was found dead in her home by her brother in June last year (2021), after she failed to collect her five-year-old son from school."The family, including her husband, her brother and his wife, and her step-parents attended the inquest in ReadingThey heard how the day of her death had been completely normal – she had dropped her son off at school in the morning, visited a friend for coffee and had spoken to her mother over the phone that afternoon.The coroner said that Mrs Wooldridge’s medical records confirmed she received her first Covid-19 jab on 4 June.Pathologist Dr Sukhvinder Ghataura told the coroner how her body had been healthy at the time of her death and how the toxicology report found no signs of alcohol or drugs in her system at the time.The only points noted were inflammation of the heart, fluid in her lungs alongside a small clot on her lungs.These, alongside menstrual irregularity and complaints of pain in her jaw and arm in the days after the vaccine, the pathologist suggested, were linked to myocarditis (inflammation of the heart)."He told the coroner: “On the balance of probabilities, she had vaccine-related problems. There is nothing else for me to hang my hat on. It is the most likely reason, in my conclusion. It is more than likely Dawn died in response to the Covid jab.”Kudos to this brave pathologist, who has more courage than all Canadian and Australian doctors combined (I always say Canadian doctors who pushed the jab are the worst, most incompetent in the world, with Australian doctors a close second!).But WE DO have a way of determining if the COVID-19 Vaccine caused a death.It’s called immunohistochemistry. You can do staining of tissues for COVID-19 nucleocapsid protein and spike protein.From a paper by Dr.Michael Palmer and Dr.Sucharit Bhakdi:"cells infected with the virus will express all viral proteins, including the spike and the nucleocapsid. In contrast, the mRNA-based COVID vaccines will induce expression only of spike"From 2022 Oct paper by Michael Morz“Case of a 76-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease who died 3 weeks after receiving his third COVID-19 vaccination...The family of the deceased requested an autopsy"“Immunohistochemistry for SARS-CoV-2 antigens (spike and nucleocapsid proteins) was performed.""Surprisingly, only spike protein but no nucleocapsid protein could be detected within the foci of inflammation in both the brain and the heart, particularly in the endothelial cells of small blood vessels. Since no nucleocapsid protein could be detected, the presence of spike protein must be ascribed to vaccination rather than to viral infection.”Immunohistochemistry for SARS-CoV-2 antigens is not being done during autopsies in United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, or UK. WHY?Because the medical authorities know that most sudden and unexplained deaths are caused by the COVID-19 mRNA Vaccines, not Long COVID. And they have been tasked by Big Pharma to protect a $200+ billion mRNA Industry AT ALL COSTS.That’s why mRNA factories continue to be built around the world. They have no intention of stopping, no matter how many people die.

新文章：斯坦利杯血栓 - NHL 冰球运动员 Brock Boeser 因深静脉血栓缺席第 7 场比赛，NHL 疫苗接种最多的球队温哥华加人队无缘斯坦利杯季后赛 - 又有 10 名运动员突然出现血栓接种 COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗的运动员被迫退役或因血栓突然死亡。就这一点而言，这对于任何人来说都不足为奇。然而，我们可能会迎来历史上第一个由疫苗伤害决定的 NHL 斯坦利杯。2024 年 5 月 20 日 - NHL 温哥华加人队冰球运动员布罗克·博瑟因腿部血栓缺席了与埃德蒙顿油人队的第 7 场比赛。埃德蒙顿赢得了第 7 场比赛，晋级西部决赛。温哥华加人队@Canucks是 NHL 中接种新冠疫苗最多的球队，其队长在 2021 年威胁球员：“如果有任何加人队球员在 9 月 22 日开始训练营时没有完全接种疫苗，霍瓦特说，一点同侪压力可以大大确保球队能够安全地一起比赛、训练和旅行”有点同侪压力吧？ 🤔我介绍了另外 10 名患有严重凝血问题的运动员，其中包括最近的一个病例：2024 年 5 月 25 日——前 NFL 辛辛那提猛虎队首轮选秀中锋比利·普莱斯因“可怕的”血栓在 29 岁时宣布退役。“4 月 24 日，我接受了紧急肺栓塞手术，切除了进入我双肺的马鞍状血栓。作为一名健康的 29 岁年轻人，发生无缘无故的肺栓塞且无法进一步进行医学解释，这令人十分恐惧”没有进一步的医学解释，因为医生要么太无能，要么太腐败，要么太“困惑”。VigiAccess 中记录了超过 100,000 例与 COVID-19 疫苗相关的血凝事件。这与“注射部位肿胀”的发生率（103,500）和“流感样疾病”的发生率（109,000）一样高。它比“注射部位红斑”（86,000）或“感觉异常”（51,000）、“注射部位发热”（51,000）和“感觉发热”（50,000）的出现频率更高。也就是说，血栓是辉瑞和Moderna新冠疫苗最常见的不良事件之一。mRNA 注射后凝血的风险极高，但医生并未告知患者这些风险，因为知情同意已不复存在。NEW ARTICLE: STANLEY CLOT - NHL Hockey Player Brock Boeser out of Game 7 with DVT blood clot and NHL's most vaxxed team, Vancouver Canucks, are out of Stanley Cup Playoffs - 10 more Athletes clotting suddenlyCOVID-19 mRNA Vaccinated Athletes are being forced to retire or are dying suddenly due to blood clots.At this point, this should come as no surprise to anyone.However, we might have the first NHL Stanley Cup in History that is decided by a Vaccine Injury.May 20, 2024 - NHL Vancouver Canucks hockey player Brock Boeser missed Game 7 with Edmonton Oilers because of a blood clot in his leg. Edmonton won Game 7 to advance to the Western Conference Final.Vancouver Canucks @Canucks were the most COVID-19 Vaccinated team in the NHL, with their Captain threatening the players in 2021:“If there are any Canucks players who arrive for the start of training camp on Sept. 22 and aren’t fully vaccinated, Horvat said a little peer pressure could go a long way in ensuring the team is able to play, practise and travel safely together”A little peer pressure huh? 🤔I present 10 additional Athletes with severe clotting issues including a very recent case:May 25, 2024 - Former NFL Cincinnati Bengals first round pick center Billy Price announced his retirement at the young age of 29 due to “terrifying” blood clot.“On April 24th I had emergency pulmonary embolism surgery to remove a saddle clot that was entering both of my lungs. As a healthy 29 year old, an unprovoked pulmonary embolism with no further medical explanation is terrifying”No further medical explanation because doctors are either too incompetent, too corrupt or too "baffled".There are over 100,000 blood clotting events recorded in VigiAccess with COVID-19 Vaccines.That’s as frequent as “injection site swelling” which is at 103,500, “influenza like illness” which is at 109,000. It’s more frequent than “injection site erythema” which is at 86,000, or “feeling abnormal” which is at 51,000, “injection site warmth” at 51,000, “feeling hot” at 50,000.In other words, blood clots are one of the most common adverse events of Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 Vaccines.The risk of clotting after mRNA jabs is extremely high but doctors have not told patients about these risks because informed consent no longer exists.

经济金融管理市场的同学每日必读:文章来自华盛顿邮报，主要讲述的是国人心中曾经的“美国梦”，曾经的美国是让中国人向往财富之地，美国品牌是高端的代表，美国电影电视更是风靡一时，连美国的月亮都比中国的圆，而现在国产品牌、国产电影全面崛起，那些记忆中厉害的美国产品和影视剧只能留在记忆中了，这背后是中国软硬实力的提升和用心打造的文化话语权。There was a time not so long ago in China when anything American was automatically seen as better. In the 1990s, weddings were held at a McDonald’s near Beijing’s Tiananmen Square. By the 2000s, Nike sneakers, iPhones and dates at Pizza Hut were the badges of middle-class achievement.曾几何时 中产的标志America, which is called “Meiguo” or “beautiful country” in Chinese, was the bastion of wealth and ease. Even the moon hung larger in the United States than in China, people used to joke. 财富和安逸的堡垒。Now, Chinese shoppers are more likely to be sipping a drink from Luckin, a Chinese coffee chain, than Starbucks or lining up all night to buy Huawei’s Mate 60 Pro than the latest Apple device. Today, no one says the moon is any different when seen from the United States.现实变化PART 02“Back in the days you looked at American brands you just felt they were cooler,” said Tracy Liu, a 30-year-old translator in Shanghai. “Now people chase after domestic brands.” 曾经高冷范For decades, this soft power was one of the United States’ most potent weapons in China. But over the last few years, the U.S. has lost hearts and minds in China as its cultural luster has faded. “It’s a paradigm shift,” said Da Wei, director of the Center for International Security and Strategy at Tsinghua University. The weakening of American soft power in China coincides with a China that is growing stronger and richer, and is working to create its own cultural cachet. 模式转变 文化声望PART 03The rise of ‘China chic’With the decline of U.S. appeal comes the rise of “China chic,” a trend encouraged by authorities but also embraced by a public that increasingly prizes domestic over foreign brands. Popular Chinese makeup brands like Huaxizi, or Florasis, use traditional Chinese medicine in their products, marketing them as better for East Asian faces. 中国风Chinese consumers in search of a high-end phone are increasingly looking at homegrown brands. Apple’s sales in China fell 19 percent in the first quarter of 2024, compared with a year ago, according to data from Counterpoint Research, while Huawei’s rose by almost 70 percent, putting the Chinese smartphone manufacturer on the brink of overtaking the American tech giant. 超越PART 04Once-dominant U.S. television shows and Hollywood movies are no longer part of the mainstream conversation. When Liu went to university in 2012, her peers were still watching U.S. shows like “Friends,” “The Big Bang Theory” and “Modern Family.” 美国派  生活大爆炸 摩登家庭Last year, Chinese film industry analysts declared the “era of Hollywood over” in China after domestic productions accounted for more than 80 percent of box office revenue. All 10 top movies by revenue were Chinese - a far cry from 2012, when U.S. films like “Mission: Impossible” and “The Avengers” accounted for seven of China’s top 10 box office hits. 2012中国市场曾经的top: 碟中谍 阿凡达PART 05Encapsulating this paradigm shift: The Central Perk coffee shop - a replica of the cafe in “Friends,” down to its fuzzy orange couch and a barista named Gunther - on the sixth floor of a mall in Beijing closed in 2020. For more than a decade, it was an enduring symbol of one of America’s strongest cultural exports to China. 时代缩影:老友记场景复制的 2020咖啡馆One of the most popular shows in the country for years, “Friends” offered a glimpse of an American way of life that seemed to Du Xin, 45, who quit his job as an engineer to start the cafe, refreshingly open and full of possibility. Whether it was due to covid restrictions or changing tastes, a skin care product shop took its place.工程师下海 (老友记美国人的生活方式充满了开放及可能性耳目一新)“Fewer people were paying for nostalgia,” Du said. Not for television nostalgia and not for American Dream nostalgia either.有关怀旧主题的感慨。

2024年4月7日，The Star Democrat发布了一篇文章：Father writes book to connect with son experiencing long COVID-父亲通过写书与正在经历长新冠的儿子建立联系。以下是大致内容： 2023年10月，Michael Smith写了《Move That Cloud》，与Dylan Smith重新建立联系，他的儿子自2022年以来一直经历着长新冠（long COVID）。 Michael希望他的书能帮助家人，因为他正在努力筹集资金来支付医疗费用，他觉得这可能会改变他儿子的生活，当Michael 的儿子感觉不适时，他通过写信向儿子表达感受。 长新冠的广泛定义是急性新冠感染后持续或发展的体征和症状，包括了200多种症状。Dylan自2022年11岁感染新冠病毒后就患上了长新冠，他的症状一直很严重，无法正常行走或进食，只能依靠鼻饲管获取营养。他经历了全身性的神经疼痛，并且由于疼痛而经历了非癫痫性发作。Michael说，任何经历过剧烈疼痛的人和他人谈话的容忍度都很低，所以当儿子因长新冠离开他、孤立自己时，他表示理解，但他想让儿子知道他爱他。 Micheal表示：“我选择了一种不同的形式，并试图让它变得发自内心。我不是作家，但我试着让它变得更有趣味性，这样这种方式就会更有效，更受欢迎。”Dylan的母亲Stacey Smith认为这本书对Michael来说就像治疗一样。她回忆起Michael给他们看这本书的那一天，他说，“Dylan，我真的很想你，很难不和你讲话。我只是想让你知道，我一直在你身边，希望有一天，我们可以一起坐下谈谈，你如何度过正在经历的这段困难时期。” 两年的时间里，Smith一家拜访了无数的医生和医院，帮助儿子从长新冠中康复，但长新冠的儿科治疗是一个缺乏研究的领域。之后，他们知道了Spero诊所的神经康复项目。该项目是一个为期14周的治疗计划，将长新冠作为一种神经系统疾病进行治疗，旨在帮助中枢神经系统恢复。Stacey说，很多与Dylan状态相似或更糟的年轻人在这个项目中得到了缓解，Smith一家正在为他们的儿子筹集资金，以便在今年6月参加这个项目。学校老师Annette English说，Dylan在长新冠之前是一个善良、聪明、有礼貌的男孩，社区应该团结起来，帮助Dyalan接受可能改变他生活的治疗。#新冠##新冠疫情##新冠病毒##新冠病毒感染与认知功能下降存在相关性##新冠肺炎##关注新冠肺炎##又一种新冠新毒株突袭多国##新冠康复日记##长新冠#

Jorie Graham confronts past, present, and future. (Article from The Harvard Gazette (USA), Updated on May 31, 2023)  Jorie Graham’s new book of poetry, “To 2040,” confronts time and mortality and the many crises shadowing what she calls “the human project.” But we still have the humanities, says the acclaimed poet and Boylston Professor of Oratory and Rhetoric. Graham emailed answers to our questions about the new book, her students, why she’s on Twitter, and more. The interview has been edited for clarity and length.Q&A:GAZETTE: Your work has always been informed by the personal, but the writing of this book coincided with several grave moments, including your mother’s passing, your husband’s serious accident, and your own cancer diagnosis. How did you find clarity amid all that grief and fear?GRAHAM: I had thought, after most of half a century of inquiry, I knew something about the nature of time. After all, lyric poetry’s most insistent querying regards the nature of time — how limited human time is (as lived), how surprisingly long it is (in imagination), how mysteriously it prolongs itself (in memory), how overwhelmingly fast it can bear down on us and break into reality (in war, in climate chaos), the fathomless actual extent of it (deep time), and its illusory nature (does it exist at all?). You’d think ( I certainly imagined) I’d covered a lot of terrain. Well, it takes little more than coming up against the absolute shutting down of time when a loved one has passed out of it, or a rip in the fabric of its still strangely sturdy illusion, and a quick glimpse through that tear — such as a drastic diagnosis might provoke — for one to feel one has to start from scratch.GAZETTE: You confront your mortality in this book. Can you talk about how poetry gave you the space to do that?GRAHAM: Mortality got my attention. And it was — as we are told to believe but rarely do — a gift. I mean, we are here to learn something. And I realized I had a lot left to learn, and, too, that I had, in poetic form, an astounding instrument by which to encounter “deeper” truths. The whole thing is a mystery. The book — one I never imagined I could write — formally in particular — was a surprise. The reality is, we all have so much left unlived, so many questions we have not yet known to ask. And we are graced if we have a skill or a vocation which can help us across the rapids when they dissolve the illusion of hard ground underfoot. I have poetry. I guess even I, after all these years, underestimated what an astounding tool kit poetic practice and form provide up against a crisis — such as illness or disappearance. Even the power of poetry’s imagination — under those circumstances — shocked me with its bolt-like intimations. Poetry’s capacity for curiosity slowly infiltrated fear, and its quickening of imagination tempered grief. Or some of it.GAZETTE: The fear and the grief — in the book you are experiencing these feelings in relation to both your own predicament and the Earth’s.GRAHAM: The crossing of tipping points toward an extinction scenario, the explosion of wars which seem unending — even newly “imaginable” nuclear wars — the fires, droughts, losses of habitat, extinctions, the looming dissolution of the democratic project, the rampant inequality increasing under the cover of COVID — the gun insanity, the microtargeting insanity, the surveillance capitalism nightmare — the coming yet more viciously to the surface of our racism, misogyny, homophobia, antisemitism — the fear of the other — the raging of all of these, felt like evermore over-expressing cells taking the human project out. So all of it is in the background (and sometimes the foreground) of the poems. It’s all one fabric unraveling. Is the crisis primarily spiritual, ethical, political? It’s hard to feel where one piece ends and the other starts — cancer scans, satellite images of the heating earth, the warming oceans, national maps of mass (and police) shootings, global maps of refugees, heart-stopping charts of poverty, income inequality, homelessness, incarceration. The loss of opportunity for whole generations. …GAZETTE: Every day, it seems, we hear about the death of the humanities. How do you see the situation, both as a teacher and a poet?GRAHAM: Perhaps the death of the humanities is exaggerated? Gen Z, we are told, appears to love books again. They apparently don’t want to read on screens and tablets. When interviewed they say — to my amazement — they love “the smell of books.” Bookstores (which we were told were going extinct, remember?) are opening and thriving. When I look at the University, I see a huge desire for the study of the humanities — more than I’ve seen in years. Does this equate with the desire to commit to certain “concentrations”? I’m not sure. I do sense that interdisciplinarity beckons. Perhaps because cross-pollination is more like life itself these days? The students who meet up in my workshops — graduates and undergraduates — no doubt benefit from “concentrating” in some discipline. But besides English, they reach my classes from law, public health, divinity, computer science, physics, economics, math, design, the Medical School, and from our labs. Their individual porous imaginations, as they meet the communal interdisciplinarity, provide the spark, as I see it, for the success Harvard is having in this arena. The publication record is extraordinary. Few MFA programs in the country match it. Writers, artists exist all over this University — so finding and connecting them, making their network live — creates the high-voltage current of imagination we call the humanities.GAZETTE: Why do you think the humanities have this kind of drawing power?GRAHAM: Because humans — even those privileged enough to be at a place like Harvard — know that life has some pretty major curveballs in it. You are not getting a pass. Will the future be secure? has never been anything but an unsettling question. Will the crop fail, will the newborn survive, will there be rain, will I find love, will my people survive, will justice prevail, will war come again. … The humanities teach us many things we crave more than ever now. They teach — don’t laugh at me — virtues. They teach us to have courage. They give us a way of understanding that we are not as alone as we think. They help us reckon with our mortality and that of those we love. They help us grapple with whatever we mean by fate, accident, chance, luck, miracle. They help us grasp cruelty, greed, brutality, evil in the human heart. They help us intuit the difference between being saved and being spared. They ask us — in the deepest way possible — do you really want to be spared? Our first answer is most often — mistakenly — yes. …  Young people alive now are going to need — as much as each generation has needed — and in some ways perhaps more — courage. And the wide aperture on the human I have just alluded to is where courage is nourished — where its capacity can be awakened. They will also need imagination — more than ever. Imagination is a form of courage, as courage is a form of imagination. The humanities are not in trouble. I wish people would see that.GAZETTE: You are active on Twitter. Can you talk about your relationship with social media and how you think about that space?GRAHAM: Actually, I had never done any social media. But I began asking my students, a few years ago, at the start of class, to share an important story they had gleaned from the news that week. The silence which often followed concerned me. I also felt they might start down some rabbit holes which were unnerving. I assigned the reading of news (I suggested they choose their own outlets), but we didn’t get very far. This followed upon my shock at discovering how few of my students had voted in 2016. So I thought, “If I get on Twitter and curate trustworthy news they will perhaps listen there.” Today such a move might not have been necessary. My current students are much more politically engaged — as we all can tell — but it turns out my little curated news each day helps a few others as well. So now I see it as a civic duty. Perhaps even a minuscule form of activism — a drop in the bucket. Of course I am also aware of what’s at risk — what Shoshana Zuboff describes in “The Age of Surveillance Capitalism” — which should be required reading.GAZETTE: Are our students ready for their futures?GRAHAM: That’s the question isn’t it? How do we help them face this future. I am always being asked about hope. How do we instill hope. Are we promoting a “hopeful” point of view. How much “reality” can we expect young people to shoulder? I have come to feel that the question is, rather, how do we instill courage. There’s a big difference between hope and courage.GAZETTE: So what would you tell your students?GRAHAM: What I tell my students, when they feel singularly unfortunate to be born in this moment, is this is your moment, the moment your soul showed up incarnate. In this world. It is an astonishing moment to be alive. You could have been born into a lull — instead you were born into a tipping point. It’s your one life and you’ve entered it at a flexion point — a point when everything you do matters. How often in history does a soul get to live in such an era? Don’t waste it. Show up for it. With everything you’ve got. Some will invent, some will organize, some will witness, some will grieve, some will console. Live this life now. Even if in fury and grief, live it. You don’t want to die not having lived. It’s incredibly easy to find a way around experience rather than through it. But you will have cheated yourself out of your only possession: your life. You are here now. Now is the time to live fully, not hide, not escape.

美国流行病学大神卡兰，因为新冠医院实况呼喊了N天，终于，加州新冠废水数据出来了，如图1-图3，波形科幻。美国流行病学大家熟悉的大神菲利普斯，发言更加精彩，如图4-图5。国内医学界，目测也大约有20%已经加入“唤醒”新冠认知行列，但是，逆转意识，需要星星点灯，每一步都会很难。台湾成功大学医学院，发表了几百人统计的论文《Unveiling Long COVID symptomatology, Co-occurrence trends, and Symptom Distress Post SARS-CoV-2 Infection》，图6，希望提醒新冠“再感染”的病痛，虽然，无法像美国退伍军人几百万人参加统计，但是，也是成功发表的论文：O网页链接我个人想“唤醒”的是：1、女性各组织，在灾难中需要作为应该注意的是：台湾这篇新冠论文，依然大部分是中青年男性参加了统计，作为长新冠/新冠后遗症占据70%比例的育龄女性，依然只是少数人参加了统计。这是现实，不是隐私，自己不作为，人家又怎么为女性新冠后遗症争取真相、探索资源与权利？2、不要滥用补品中国不缺是水军，不要盲目听信，见虚就补。新冠后遗症，大部分根源是残留的新冠病毒库，可以理解为中医的“实邪未清”和传统禁忌，并且，病毒在体内不断进化。另外，新冠也不是只有ACE2一个通道，不能盲目相信一些体外科研，引狼入室。滥用补品的，等到天亮时，会连我都没有办法。备注：卡兰在斯坦福大学官网的荣誉资料，如图2

今天早上去听了LJI Shane Crotty来做的报告（微博正文）。我上次听他讲座还是我PhD时老板邀请的。他用一张幻灯片讲了两周前他和Schief合作发的Science（微博正文），我本来想问他有没有中和，没想他闪得太快。然后他讲了新冠。新冠的内容稍微浅显，因为他是做疫苗的，而这里主要是做抗病毒药的；但是他的叙事结构非常流畅。Crotty本身是做Tfh的，而Sette是做CD8的。他今天从2020年和Sette组合作那篇Cell文章开始讲起（微博正文），这篇Cell是Dr. Fauci在2020年到国会做听证时手里拿着的文章，也是Crotty Linkedin的背景图片。他从这篇文章开始，讲到了用同样患者队列后来做了记忆B细胞、抗体（中和抗体和黏膜IgA）研究，再做疫苗接种后的整个免疫系统的biomarker（标记物）研究以及疫苗持久性研究，目前在做Long COVID研究，这些都是新冠疫情4年来每个时期最热门的新冠免疫学研究。我问他目前美国上市的疫苗都是Spike疫苗，而NSP12等抗原却是T细胞保守表位，怎么衔接这种T细胞免疫应答的差距。他做了很详细的回答。其实这也是我过去3年的工作，就是在Spike诱导体液免疫应答的基础上，添加T细胞抗原（微博正文），以开发诱导记忆更持久的特异性T细胞免疫应答的next-gen（新一代）新冠疫苗；而他可能没有料到听众里有跟他研究方向一致的。我还有太多细节问题和技术问题，恨不得一直问下去。如果这是在AAI或者Keystone上，他肯定会被我这种“同行”问得烦不胜烦，然后皱起眉头觉得我是他竞争实验室的postdoc专门来scoop他的。 2美国·City of Foster City

需要翻译嘛？ 美国首屈一指的医学咨询机构之一发表了一份长达 265 页的报告，对长期慢性阻塞性肺气肿发表了看法，承认这种疾病对数百万美国人的严重性和顽固性。美国国家科学、工程和医学科学院是一家非政府机构，负责就科学和医学问题向联邦机构提供建议，该机构称，自冠状病毒大流行开始至今已有四年多时间，长COVID仍在损害许多人的工作能力。 报告说："长COVID可影响人的一生，从儿童到老年人，以及不同性别、种族、民族和其他人口群体，"报告得出结论说："长COVID与一系列新的或恶化的健康状况有关，包含200多种症状，几乎涉及每个器官系统。"

user_name: 中国对外贸易杂志英文版
content: 【Foreign enterprises tap into China's evolving market】 Foreign investors are intensifying their presence in China by opening new stores, launching innovative products, signing more cooperation contracts, and building production plants and R&D centers.In the first four months of 2024, the number of newly established foreign-invested enterprises in China rose 19.2 percent year-on-year to 16,805, data from the Ministry of Commerce shows.A survey of more than 600 foreign-funded companies shows that over 70 percent of them are optimistic about the development prospects of the Chinese market over the next five years, and more than 50 percent believe the Chinese market has become more attractive, according to the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade.The robust recovery of the Chinese economy, combined with the country's ever-improving business environment, has increasingly drawn the attention of foreign-invested companies, as they actively seek out new growth opportunities.Seizing opportunities in changing marketThe resilience of China's massive consumer market has left a strong impression on foreign investors, particularly amidst the lukewarm global recovery. The growth momentum in the market has made it increasingly attractive for multinationals to seize new opportunities by better adapting to market changes."We can feel the recovery of the consumer market in China," said Arjun Purkayastha, senior vice-president of Reckitt Greater China, noting that the company's revenue in China rose in the first half of 2023 and the growth continued in the past few quarters across its brands.China's tourism market rebounded quickly with the easing of Covid-19 prevention and control at the beginning of last year, and foreign-invested firms have made ambitious plans accordingly.During the first quarter of this year, hotel group Marriott International reported a 6 percent year-on-year increase in average revenue per available room in the Greater China region. This growth outpaced the global average growth of the company, according to Mao Yibing, president of Marriott International Greater China.Last year, Marriott signed nearly 100 hotel contracts in China, up 55 percent from 2022, according to Mao."China has a large population and vast market space, and the demand for diversified and high-end consumption is increasing day by day," said Frederico Freire Jardim, Asia president of US food maker Kraft Heinz.French retailer Decathlon recently launched its professional road bike brand to tap China's huge cycling market. The company has expanded its product line to more than 80 sports in recent years to support people in different age groups and with different abilities.Vincent Boinay, president of L'Oreal North Asia Zone and CEO of L'Oreal China, said he is deeply impressed by the rapid changes in the Chinese market. To meet the growing demand in China's e-commerce market, L'Oreal opened its first self-built smart fulfillment center globally in Suzhou, Jiangsu province, in April. The center can process 50 million direct-to-consumer orders and 17 million cases for business-to-business customers each year."China opportunity" is still the key word valued by foreign-funded enterprises, said Patricia Xia, consulting firm Ernst & Young (EY) China central managing partner, adding that these companies are still confident in the Chinese market and are exploring more opportunities in emerging industries and niche markets.Sharing benefits of china's opening up, innovationOn May 31, Beijing passed its first special regulation on foreign investment, highlighting measures including promoting the secure and orderly cross-border flow of data, recognizing overseas vocational qualifications, and conducting regular consultations between local governments and foreign companies.This exemplifies China's efforts to promote further opening up and boost its appeal to global investors.This year, China has taken a series of measures to facilitate foreign investment, including rolling out national and pilot free trade zone versions of negative lists for cross-border trade in services, and simplifying visa application procedures for foreigners.Talking about China's series of policies on facilitating foreign investment and the flow of people, Xia said such moves demonstrate the country's determination to continuously expand openness to the outside world, actively optimize the business environment for foreign investment, and promote cooperation and mutual benefits.China's sound manufacturing industry and complete supply chain, coupled with a sustained and stable policy environment, provide a strong guarantee for foreign companies to strengthen their confidence in long-term investment in the country, said Leon Wang, executive vice president, chair and president of international region and China president of British biopharmaceutical company AstraZeneca, adding that the company always has confidence in China's market, manufacturing and innovation.According to Xia, the Chinese market is not only a critical source of revenue for many foreign-invested enterprises but more importantly, an innovation hub to develop new solutions and intellectual properties benefiting global markets.From 2012 to 2021, the R&D investment pooled by major foreign-funded industrial enterprises in China soared by 91.5 percent, and the number of valid invention patents grew from 68,000 to 241,000, statistics show.The rapid development of artificial intelligence technology in China is of great help in the fields such as drug research and development, as well as molecule structure design, Wang said.Reckitt is also willing to enhance R&D capabilities and invest in local talent to deliver more disruptive China-first innovations. By 2026, it plans to establish a Global R&D Center of Excellence in Shanghai, according to Purkayastha.

2024年4月3日，ABC News发布了一篇文章：Experts call for more research into long COVID, as study reveals high prevalence in WA-专家呼吁对长新冠进行更多研究，因为研究表明西澳流行率很高。以下是大致内容： 研究人员表示，需要为新冠感染相关长期症状的患者提供更多支持，新数据显示，大量西澳人因严重长新冠（long COVID）症状而无法工作。澳大利亚国立大学（ANU）调查了西澳2022年奥密克戎流行期间，11000名新冠检测呈阳性的人。今年3月发表的研究发现，近20%的感染者三个月后仍有疲劳、记忆丧失和注意力难以集中等症状。 首席研究员Mulu Woldegiorgis称，关于长新冠的现有数据很少，但这项研究表明，西澳的长新冠比例很高。 这是大流行早期澳大利亚长新冠比例数据的两倍多，高于英国和加拿大的类似研究数据。Woldegiorgis博士认为，认真对待长新冠患者的症状非常重要，调查数据显示有超过六分之一的人因为持续症状无法完全恢复到工作或学习中。 Joanna Lewis在近两年前感染了新冠病毒，几周后，当她仍有持续症状时，她甚至怀疑自己可能又感染了其他病毒。她经历了POTS（体位性心动过速综合征）-长新冠症状之一，这意味着当她坐着或站着时，心率每分钟会飙升30次以上。她不得不辞职休息，花光了积蓄，还收留了寄宿生以维持生计，最近，这位42岁的“老人”又开始饱受疲劳症状的折磨。她一天中的大部分时间都需要躺着休息，这意味着生命周期变得无比渺小。 全科医生Michael Livingston说，他在西澳行医期间，见过许多出现了不明原因的疲劳和脑雾症状的患者，很多年轻人感染新冠后并没有像想象中的那样快速恢复。有些人患上了痴呆症，因为他们的记忆力和简单任务处理能力都出现了有明显衰退。Livingston博士认为长新冠可能是关键因素，并敦促人们不要懈怠于预防新冠感染，他认为当局应该迅速采取长新冠应对措施。西澳卫生部长Amber-Jade Sanderson表示，他们正在密切关注与长新冠有关的任何研究证据。#新冠##长新冠##新冠肺炎##新冠病毒##新冠病毒感染与认知功能下降存在相关性##新冠疫情##新冠康复日记##又一种新冠新毒株突袭多国##关注新冠肺炎##新冠后遗症#
此时呼吸已经像拉风箱了我真觉得是long covid

口服抗新冠“神药P药”治疗长新冠（long COVID）无效！P药就是Paxlovid，由2个蛋白酶抑制剂（奈玛特韦/利托那韦）组成；截止到目前，尚无可靠的长新冠治疗方案；       由155位长新冠症状超过16个月的患者参与的临床研究，用Paxlovid治疗15天，随访15周，没能达到预期效果，包括比安慰剂更加缓解疲劳、脑雾、气短、周身疼痛、消化道症状或心血管症状；       辉瑞表示，这一结果并不影响其他尝试用P药治疗长新冠的合作；Paxlovid是全美在新冠疫情中最常见的抗病毒处方药，申请上市时III期临床研究结果：降低无疫苗接种且高风险罹患重症患者住院和死亡风险90%；在另一个研究中，Paxlovid对一般风险包括疫苗接种者，没有治疗利益。#长新冠治疗##Paxlovid##健闻登顶计划#

Historically, presidents could count on the “justice system” overlooking their crimes. As long as they put the interests of the ruling class as a whole above their own, they would be absolved of the occasional sexual assault or mass murder. Donald Trump is different. The ruling class longs for political stability, but his presidency was a chaotic whirlwind. He consciously violated many of the “norms” of capitalist politics. The ruling class needs to make an example of him as a warning to future political mavericks.Whether they will succeed is in doubt. In a recent opinion poll, 67% of voters said a guilty verdict would not affect their vote in November. Only 17% said a conviction would make them less likely to vote Trump. Despite the capitalist media’s extensive coverage of The Donald’s manifold legal problems, most Americans remain stubbornly focused on such trivialities as rising food and housing costs and the ongoing bloodletting in Gaza—rather than the weighty issues surrounding Trump’s payoffs to an adult film actress.Regardless of its effect on the 2024 race, the verdict is the latest indication that turmoil and instability are the new normality for American capitalism. The last half decade witnessed the Covid crisis, the BLM uprising, the January 6 riots, a deep recession, and skyrocketing inflation. Now Americans have the chance to see a convicted felon running for—and possibly winning—the presidency.This can only accelerate declining faith in the once august institutions built up over centuries to secure and defend capitalist rule. A 2023 Gallup poll found only 17% of Americans have “a great deal or quite a lot of confidence” in the criminal justice system. Trump and the Republicans’ attacks on the legal system will only discredit it further.
2022年9月的我。2023年5月的我。阿克萨大洪水到如今的我。

2024年6月7日，NewsNation发布了一篇文章：COVID-19 may be linked to rare cancers: Doctors-医生表面：新冠可能与罕见癌症有关。以下是大致内容： Bonnie和Bob Krall是一对已婚夫妇，他们相对平稳地度过了新冠大流行时期，Bonnie有一些轻微感染期症状，Bob是一位无症状感染者。Bonni说：“我们都很健康，我们刚结束了美国西部的长途旅行，回来后就好像砰的一声，Bob被确诊了。”Bob并非感染了新冠，而是患上了两种非常罕见的癌症，随后，Bonnie也出现了类似情况。她告诉我们，她的腹部发现了一个8.5磅重的肿瘤，她在去年12月份很健康，直到4月份，他们被诊断出了癌症。 新冠感染者正在不断增长，然后一些感染者患上了罕见的癌症，通常不止一种，Krall夫妇就是其中之一。Krall夫妇的医生Kashyap Patel博士表示，他们逐渐注意到了一些非同寻常的模式，他和他在Carolina Blood和癌症护理协会的同事记录了新冠感染与癌症之间的一些非常令人担忧的联系：新患者增加了20-30%；出现了很大个患有多种癌症的患者；夫妻和兄弟姐妹在几个月内同时患上癌症；癌症患者病情缓解数年后复发； Patel博士称，经常伴随着新冠感染出现的长新冠（long COVID）和炎症可能是找到与人们正在出现的癌症之间联系的关键。“炎症会引发基因组的许多基因变化，从而使某些的身体人产生了癌症倾向。我目前正在分析近300名患有长新冠的感染者体内炎症生物标志物的数据，以及他们是否出现了不寻常的癌症。”对Bob和Bonnie来说，目前的预后至少还不错，Bob的病情正在缓解，Bonnie已接近好转。但是，如果想确切了解这类状况为什么会发生在他们身上，可能还需要很长的时间。谁知道呢？我们目前还没办法完全了解。#长新冠##新冠肺炎##新冠病毒##新冠疫情##新冠康复日记##新冠##新冠后遗症##又一种新冠新毒株突袭多国##关注新冠肺炎#

content: [高焦] 看到林总 @林步里 那边提到了大漂亮国家科学工程及医学院(National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine)开始抢夺LC的定义 微博正文 感觉还是有点无耻的，毕竟最开始这帮老爷们否定了Long Covid的存在，毕竟这完全是病友们交流出来的用词，按照一些笃信“免疫债”的科普圈(juàn)人士的话术，这就是妥妥的民科啊。只不过统计数据做的较好的欧美在新疫情时代In Waves的大版本下，健康的劳动力因为“长期疾病”的原因不断退出市场，另一方面残疾人的劳动参与率反而上升，纸最终还是包不住火了。一个由于否认客观事实一度被打成“民科”的概念最终还是得到了承认，总归是件进步的事吧，那么，古尔丹，代价是什么呢？无独有偶，近日美国医学会杂志(JAMA)上线了一篇关于中招后出现较为严重MISC症状的儿童后继的神经系统表现与新发病率的文章 (截图见 图1) ，神秘doi代码： 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2024.14122 什么意思呢？就是【益生菌19】的严重后遗症MISC的后遗症，也不知道哪些笃定【益生菌19】症状就是“小感冒”、“没有后遗症”、“LC就是心理问题”的砖家 (图2) 们怎么看待这些后遗症的后遗症？具体的内容就不搬运了，之前因为辛苦搬运过一篇儿童【益生菌19】后遗症的综述，被夹国光速没收，现在连链接都找不到了(通常的夹法只是自己可见)，无论夹国的后台有没有审核论文的能力，反正有“赔医生”、“拖把”这样的致命健康大V活蹦乱跳地存在，证明了白区对于花朵们并不关心。反正该说的也都说了，至于一些家长是不是要决定让自己的孩子去刷病毒库，除了对这些被送去玩轮盘赌的花朵们表示同情又能做什么呢？最后还是要提醒一下，不想得LC就别去得C。少得一次C胜读数年书。#AnythingButCovid##好日子在后头呢##我们都有光明的未来#

抗体或自身抗体可能是长新冠（long COVID）的病因！现在至少有3个理论解释长新冠的病因：新冠病毒在体内持续复制、凝血机制障碍导致微血管堵塞和存在自身抗体（autoantibody）；       研究者从长新冠患者血中提取IgG——最常见的抗体，共计34位，平均43岁，在疫情头两年感染新冠，但是轻症，长新冠症状是疲劳和慢性疼痛；把分离到的IgG抗体注射入小鼠，增加疼痛敏感性，并有明显运动障碍；这为“自身抗体”理论加了分！       如这个结论成立，长新冠患者就不能献血了，这真是个蛮严重的问题；小剂量地塞米松很可能有效，或其他抗炎治疗会有疗效！#健闻登顶计划# #长新冠#
大概率属于"long COVID"，需要修养，调理。转发原文：抱歉，根据作者设置的微博可见时间范围，此微博已不可见。

content: 新文章：槲皮素和癌症 - 过去 4 年的新研究 - 回顾了 5 篇论文槲皮素是一种强效的黄酮类化合物，存在于多种植物、水果和蔬菜中。它具有抗氧化、抗炎和抗癌作用。大多数人服用槲皮素是为了治疗过敏和肥大细胞活化综合征，但其抗癌作用非常重要。我回顾了过去五年有关槲皮素对癌症影响的文献。槲皮素的主要抗癌作用包括：- 调节 ROS（活性氧）- 刺激癌细胞凋亡- 刺激细胞周期停滞- 刺激自噬- 抑制肿瘤血管生成- 抑制转移- 槲皮素可以预防某些癌症的形成，主要是结直肠癌。槲皮素的一些独特抗癌作用与那些接种辉瑞或 Moderna COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗并患上涡轮癌（乳腺癌、结直肠癌、肺癌、胰腺癌等）的人有关- 槲皮素可稳定 p53 并提高 p53 水平，从而通过细胞凋亡导致癌细胞死亡（p53 被 COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗刺突蛋白破坏）- 槲皮素能够杀死癌症干细胞（导致恶性癌症、转移和癌症复发 - Turbo Cancer 患者的预后极差，因为标准化疗不会杀死他们的癌症干细胞）- 槲皮素调节与多种癌症有关的微小RNA（miR）（mRNA诱导的涡轮癌理论之一是致癌miR的存在或上调）- 槲皮素对多种癌症的研究最为深入，其中乳腺癌和结直肠癌就是其中之一。- 槲皮素在小鼠体内的研究表明其对乳腺癌、结肠直肠癌、肝癌、前列腺癌、肺癌、胰腺癌、黑色素瘤、白血病、胃癌具有抗癌作用。槲皮素与许多其他治疗方法具有协同作用：- 槲皮素与化疗具有协同作用，可提高杀死癌细胞的功效- 槲皮素与放射疗法具有协同作用- 槲皮素可逆转化疗药物耐药性（对于对标准化疗产生耐药性的 Turbo Cancer 患者至关重要）- 槲皮素与生物活性化合物（白藜芦醇、绿茶儿茶素 EGCG）具有协同作用槲皮素存在于多种植物中，每 100 克植物中含量最高的是洋葱（45 毫克）、牛至（42 毫克）、荞麦（36 毫克）、菠菜（27 毫克）、蔓越莓（25 毫克）、羽衣甘蓝（23 毫克）、樱桃（17 毫克）、蓝莓（15 毫克）、芦笋（14 毫克）。槲皮素是安全的，目前已有许多生物利用度更高的配方。槲皮素应包含在大多数“替代癌症治疗”方案中。其中一些研究的结论：“槲皮素作为天然产物，是一种黄酮类化合物，合理剂量的槲皮素无毒无害，且对多种肿瘤形成方式有抑制作用。”“大量的体内外实验表明，槲皮素具有很强的促细胞凋亡、抑制转移作用，以及调节细胞周期和肿瘤血管生成的能力。槲皮素可以通过调节表观遗传学来影响肿瘤的发展，可以直接调节miRNA的表达和DNA甲基化水平，发挥抗癌作用，增强肿瘤细胞对化疗的敏感性”“槲皮素具有一些显著的抗癌活性。研究表明，槲皮素通过调节与细胞凋亡和自噬相关的不同失调信号通路，利用多种机制发挥其抗癌作用”“迫切需要在该领域进行不同的体内研究，以分析槲皮素的治疗活性和安全性。”“在天然植物提取物中，槲皮素表现出多种显著的生物抗肿瘤作用。ncRNA（非编码RNA，包括miRNA和lncRNA长链非编码RNA）在癌症发展中起着关键作用。槲皮素调节ncRNA的表达，进而影响相关信号通路基因/蛋白质的表达，抑制癌细胞生长，促进细胞凋亡，增强对化疗药物的敏感性。总之，槲皮素是一种天然化合物，在癌症的辅助治疗中具有潜在的抗癌作用。”NEW ARTICLE: QUERCETIN and CANCER - New research of the past 4 years - 5 papers reviewedQuercetin is a powerful flavonoid found in a variety of plants, fruits and vegetables.It has anti-oxidant, anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer effects.Most people take Quercetin for allergies and Mast Cell Activation Syndrome, but the anti-cancer effects are very important.I review the past 5 years worth of literature on the effects of Quercetin on CANCER.Quercetin's main anti-cancer effects include:- regulates ROS (reactive oxygen species)- stimulates apoptosis of cancer cells- stimulates cell cycle arrest- stimulates autophagy- inhibits angiogenesis in tumors- inhibits metastases- Quercetin can PREVENT certain cancers from forming, mainly Colorectal cancer.Some of Quercetin's UNIQUE anti-cancer effects are relevant to those who took Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 mRNA Vaccines and developed Turbo Cancer (breast cancer, colorectal cancer, lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, etc)- Quercetin stabilizes p53 and increases p53 levels which leads to cancer cell death via apoptosis (p53 is damaged by COVID-19 mRNA Vaccine spike protein)- Quercetin is able to kill CANCER STEM CELLS (responsible for aggressive cancers, metastases and cancer recurrence - Turbo Cancer patients have extremely poor prognosis because standard chemo doesn't kill their Cancer Stem Cells)- Quercetin regulates microRNAs (miRs) which are implicated in many cancers (one of the theories on mRNA Induced Turbo Cancer is the presence or upregulation of oncogenic miRs)- Best studied cancers with Quercetin are breast cancer and colorectal cancer.- Quercetin in vivo mouse studies show anti-cancer effects in: breast, colorectal, liver, prostate, lung, pancreatic, melanoma, leukemia, gastricQuercetin is synergistic with many other treatments:- Quercetin is synergistic with chemo and increases efficacy of cancer cell killing - Quercetin is synergistic with radiation therapy- Quercetin reverses chemo drug resistance (crucial for Turbo Cancer patients who have resistance to standard chemotherapy treatments)- Quercetin is synergistic with bioactive compounds (resveratrol, green tea catechins EGCG)Quercetin is found in a variety of plants, highest concentrations in onions (45mg), oregano (42mg), buckwheat (36mg), spinach (27mg), cranberry (25mg), kale (23mg), cherries (17mg), blueberries (15mg), asparagus (14mg) per 100 grams.Quercetin is safe and is now available in many formulations that are more bioavailable.Quercetin should be in most "Alternative Cancer Treatment" regimens.Conclusions of some of these studies:“As a natural product, quercetin is a flavonoid compound, and treated with a reasonable dose of quercetin is non-toxic and has various inhibitory effects on various ways of tumor formation.”“A large number of in vivo and in vitro experiments have shown that quercetin has a strong role in promoting apoptosis, inhibiting metastasis, and its ability to regulate cell cycle and tumor angiogenesis. Quercetin can influence the development of tumor by regulating epigenetics, which can directly regulate the expression of miRNA and the level of DNA methylation to exert anti-cancer effect and enhance the sensitivity of tumor cells to chemotherapy”“Quercetin possesses some significant anticancer activities. It has been shown that quercetin uses multiple mechanisms to exert its anticancer effects by modulating different dysregulated signalling pathways which implicated apoptosis and autophagy”“there is an urgent need for different in vivo studies in this field to analyze the therapeutic activities and safety of quercetins.”“Among natural plant extracts, quercetin shows several significant biological anti-tumor effects. ncRNA (non-coding RNA including miRNA and lncRNA long non-coding RNA) plays a key role in cancer development. Quercetin regulates the expression of ncRNAs, which in turn affects the related signalling pathway genes/proteins expression, suppresses the cancer cell growth, promotes cell apoptosis, and enhances sensitivity to chemotherapy agents. Taken together, quercetin is a natural compound with a potential anticancer effect in the adjuvant treatment of cancers.”

无论是生酮，断食，还是任何其他方法，食材，等，都是他人的总结，他人的体验，只起到参考的作用，别拿到篮里就是菜，必须自己仔细研究，考虑自身实际状况，再做决定。新文章：我禁食了 5 天 - 禁食 3 天和 5 天的区别 - 定期禁食的健康益处（以及关于 Buchinger 禁食法、长期 COVID 和长期 COVID 疫苗的最新研究）我最近禁食了五天，这真是一段难忘的经历！我诚实地讲述了我挣扎的过程，从 48 小时后的头痛，72 小时后的脱水、肌肉无力和发烧，96 小时后的精疲力竭，到第 5 天相对轻松，并在 5 天内减轻了 13.3 磅的体重。为什么要禁食 5 天而不是 3 天？- 持续自噬的好处- 免疫系统重启的好处- 肠道干细胞持续增加- 酮体生成持续增加- 进一步减轻体重关于 5 天或更长时间（最长 21 天）定期禁食益处的最大规模同行评审研究2019（Toledo 等人）——一项包括 1422 名受试者的观察性研究中，4 至 21 天禁食期间的安全性、健康改善和幸福感- 1422 名受试者禁食 4 至 21 天。- 禁食分为 5、10、15、20 天- 使用 Buchinger 周期性禁食法- 93.2% 的人⬆️身体和情绪健康- 84.4% (341/404) 的患者报告原有健康问题得到显著改善- 报告的不良事件少于 1%（无严重事件）Buchinger 定期禁食：定期禁食(PF)医疗计划由德国医生 Otto Buchinger 开发，用于治疗肥胖症和代谢及炎症病症，在中欧享有盛誉该方案包括每日临床监测、每天摄入 2-3 升水和 250 千卡食物，以及包括健康教育和体育活动在内的多学科计划。5天至20天禁食的结果：- 体重明显减轻， ⬇️腹围- 血压明显下降- 血脂水平明显下降- 血糖水平和糖化血红蛋白 (HbA1c) 显著下降安全性：对 1422 名受试者而言是安全的，只有 2 名受试者必须中断禁食，0.7% 的受试者出现不良反应，但无严重反应那么谁应该考虑 5 天禁食？好吧，每个人，但特别是：1. 癌症患者或高风险人群2. 长期新冠肺炎患者3. 长期 COVID-19 mRNA 疫苗患者4. 免疫系统有问题的患者为什么要使用长期 COVID（或长期 COVID 疫苗）？2023 年 11 月 (Grundler 等人) - 长期禁食对长期 COVID 患者的影响——病例系列和文献综述14 名患者中有 13 名报告称，禁食使他们感觉整体健康状况有所改善（其中一名没有改善）常见（疲劳、呼吸困难、肌肉和关节疼痛）和不常见（认知障碍、嗅觉和味觉障碍）的长期 COVID-19 后遗症均得到改善结论：“这凸显了长期禁食作为管理和治疗长期 COVID 的有效干预措施的潜力。”NEW ARTICLE: I FASTED FOR 5 DAYS - Difference between Fasting 3 days and 5 days - Health Benefits of Periodic Fasting (and recent research on the Buchinger Fasting Method, Long COVID and Long COVID Vaccine)I recently fasted for 5 days, it is quite the experience!I provide an honest account of my struggles, from headaches at 48hr, dehydration, muscle weakness and feeling feverish at 72hr, wiped out at 96hr, to having a relatively easy Day 5 and a weight loss of 13.3 lb over the 5 day period.Why a 5 day fast instead of 3 days?- benefits of ongoing autophagy- benefits of immune system reboot- intestinal stem cells continue to increase- ketone production continues to increase- more weight lossLargest peer reviewed study on the benefits of Periodic Fasting for 5 days or longer (up to 21 days)2019 (Toledo et al) - Safety, health improvement and well-being during a 4 to 21-day fasting period in an observational study including 1422 subjects- 1422 subjects fasted between 4 and 21 days.- they were grouped into fasting 5, 10, 15, 20 days- Used the Buchinger Periodic Fasting Method- 93.2% had ⬆️ in physical and emotional well being- 84.4% (341/404) reported significant improvement in pre-existing health complaints- less than 1% reported adverse events (none severe)Buchinger Periodic Fasting:A medical program of periodic fasting (PF) developed by the German physician Otto Buchinger to treat obesity and metabolic and inflammatory pathologies, well-known in central EuropeThe protocol involved daily clinical monitoring, intake of 2–3 L of water per day and 250 kcal of food, as well as a multi-disciplinary program including health education and physical activity.Results of 5 day to 20 day fasting:- marked weight loss, ⬇️ abdominal circumference- significant decrease in Blood pressure- significant decrease in blood lipid levels- significant decrease in glucose levels and HbA1cSafety: safe for 1422 subjects, only 2 had to interrupt fasting, 0.7% had adverse effects, none seriousSo who should consider 5 day fasting? Well, everyone but especially:1. Cancer patients or those at increased risk2. Long COVID-19 patients3. Long COVID-19 mRNA Vaccine patients4. Patients with immune system problemsWhy Long COVID (or Long COVID Vaccine)?2023 Nov (Grundler et al) - Improvements during long-term fasting in patients with long COVID – a case series and literature review13 out of 14 patients reported that fasting caused an enhancement in their perceived overall health (one had no improvement)Both frequent (fatigue, breathlessness, muscle and joint pains) and less frequent (cognitive impairment, smell and taste disorders) long term COVID-19 sequelae amelioratedConclusion: “This highlights the potential of long-term fasting as an effective intervention for managing and treating Long COVID.”

"Distractibility, trouble organizing thoughts and tasks, and losing track of conversations and items are commonly experienced by those with ADHD as well as those with brain fog due to other conditions, like long COVID (symptoms that persist for an extended period of time after having had COVID-19), illness, or lack of sleep." content: 因为睡眠/障碍混混沌沌去年查了很多关于long - Covid / after-effects of Covid 的literature review 确定自己是在漫长的恢复期中 但最近心情太坏睡眠每况愈下 去医院医生给我开的首个药方竟是要我振作起来…无语凝噎了 好像把我当做社会垃圾了一样

content: 站着累，坐着累，荨麻疹，这long covid也太可怕了

新冠病毒能不能在自愈后被人体彻底的清除？￼已经有研究表明，新冠病毒可以突破血脑屏障、在人体内多器官进行繁殖，而且这种繁殖是可以在呼吸道早已检测不到病毒的情况下长时间持续。那是否意味着，只要有过一次感染，便将终身无法彻底清除体内的新冠病毒呢？查看问题描述关注问题写回答60 个回答￼麻瓜￼2022 年度新知答主新冠“自愈”半年以上依然有新冠病毒，不会彻底清除。只不过病毒载量下降1亿倍，但在肺、心血管、免疫系统和神经系统还是有残存的病毒。--目前最新数据是Nature两周前发的文章[1]。￼新冠症状出现后7个月，依然有病毒，但病毒载量会变得很低，主要在肺、心血管系统、免疫系统、神经系统中，每1ug RNA含1-100个病毒。每1ug RNA含1-100个病毒是什么概念呢？换算下来，米粒大小的组织（50mg）有100ug RNA，大概含100-10000个新冠病毒，也不算多。而新冠感染初期，米粒大小的50mg肺组织含100亿个病毒，降到还剩100-10000个病毒，已经降很低了。￼注意，这里每个时间点都是不同人的全身组织病毒载量，每个时间点的人有个体差异，单个时间点不准，可以看前后趋势上面这张是人体各组织在新冠感染后不同时间的病毒载量，其中最后一列是感染后230天，身体各组织的病毒。可以看到，感染后第一周病毒载量很高（热图红色），四周后降得很快，随后病毒以低载量（热图蓝色）持续存在几个月。具体换算到组织切片，就长下面这样，紫色的是神经元，绿色的是病毒，还是有病毒留下来。￼总体来说不用太恐慌，7个月病毒下降1亿倍，剩下的病毒不多。但不多不代表完全没有，你的肺、心脏、神经里可能还有病毒，不同人也有个体差异。只能说，新冠“阴”后也不要太浪。参考^Stein SR, Ramelli SC, Grazioli A, Chung JY, Singh M, Yinda CK, Winkler CW, Sun J, Dickey JM, Ylaya K, Ko SH, Platt AP, Burbelo PD, Quezado M, Pittaluga S, Purcell M, Munster VJ, Belinky F, Ramos-Benitez MJ, Boritz EA, Lach IA, Herr DL, Rabin J, Saharia KK, Madathil RJ, Tabatabai A, Soherwardi S, McCurdy MT; NIH COVID-19 Autopsy Consortium; Peterson KE, Cohen JI, de Wit E, Vannella KM, Hewitt SM, Kleiner DE, Chertow DS. SARS-CoV-2 infection and persistence in the human body and brain at autopsy. Nature. 2022 Dec;612(7941):758-763. doi: 10.1038/s41586-022-05542-y. Epub 2022 Dec 14. PMID: 36517603; PMCID: PMC9749650.编辑于 2023-01-05 23:50赞同 1193收起相关推荐你馋了吗？做一盆“毛血旺”简单吃一口微博的广告￼感染了新冠严重吗？KillTuberculosis的文章 · 245 赞同￼新型冠状病毒肺炎有什么后遗症?高于科普的回答￼新冠治愈的人现在怎么样了？高于科普的回答￼更多回答￼林步里谢邀@别爱我戒了我来纠正一下某个高赞答案。我看很多人举例子都是在大体老师体内检测到，现在并无研究表明在新冠痊愈患者活体内发现病毒的，连极低浓度的病毒都检测不到。事实是，医学领域有在康复后的患者中，活体发现病毒。比如说，在肺移植的病例里，移植过程中，在供体中发现残留病毒。移植前供体主人鼻咽检测新冠呈阴性，但移植后，术后发现胸部影像显示双肺不均匀浑浊，对供体肺BAL样本进行PCR检测结果呈阳性。￼该病例强调了在标准术前评估中可能会遗漏供体新冠感染。尽管供体主人鼻咽拭子呈阴性，但供体组织中可能残留存在。类似病例还有，减肥手术中，在胃和胆囊组织中发现病毒颗粒，胃和胆囊组织长时间保留病毒残余。￼活体康复者，因为活体，没法像大体老师那样解刨器官组织一探究竟。但不代表活体康复者中没有残留病毒。所以，很难讲被人体彻底清除。科研现实是，存在着病毒长期在器官中停留的现象，目前也被研究人员列为long covid的原因之一。阅读全文赞同 921￼Eidosper关注价值、国产芯片与科技进展我的个人直观感受和“林优里”知友的说法是接近的，我倾向于我现在的不良状态，很大程度上应该是病毒的残余还没解决。比如偶尔的咳痰，这大概率是因为还有零碎的病毒时不时来搞一下，不然不大可能会有这种奇怪的症状。我个人新冠退烧应该是在12.26附近，到现在两周有余，各种问题都还没彻底解决。也许过非常久，新冠病毒终究能被清除，但应该需要相当长的时间。阅读全文赞同 37￼萧煮夫广西师范大学 MBA有的人可能可以，如身边全是羊可自己到现在还没阳准备进决赛圈的那些种子选手。大部分人目前看，是共存，清除，可能又被感染。阅读全文赞同 78热门推荐经常做什么会让一个人的气质变猥琐？80.3K 关注 · 5.7K 回答￼给你喜欢却不能在一起的人说一句话，你会说什么？23.6K 关注 · 7.1K 回答绝对零度如果达到会怎么样？人类现在能做到的最低温度是多少呢？906 关注 · 66 回答￼为什么铂金钻石段位可以和uzi打的有来有回？811 关注 · 389 回答￼古人如果吃到到现代食物饮料，会给出什么评价？10.1K 关注 · 1.1K 回答￼如何评价《向往的生活》第二季第十四期？923 关注 · 454 回答￼女生妆前妆后区别有多大？9.1K 关注 · 843 回答￼懂医学是种怎样的体验？23.9K 关注 · 1.4K 回答￼女人在婚前与婚后的生活状态是否存在差别？11.6K 关注 · 729 回答￼上大学真的很美好吗？27.5K 关注 · 4.8K 回答￼

content: LC的二三事超话 重新发一下有关LC的智商税合订本。话说，之前咱蹭硅谷大佬的热点，搞了个LC相关智商税的带货汇总贴，不知道各位还有没有印象（微博正文）~凑巧的是，Nature发了篇专题报道，也提到了一嘴这些熟悉的智商税们详见图一，这个是前段时间Nature官方公众号的官方翻译……标题复读一遍：《长新冠仍无药可医，这群患者决定自己研究》原文传送门：O长新冠仍无药可医，这群患者决定自己研究 |《自然》长文具体内容懒得一一搬运了，反正都是中文，各位自行去Nature公众号看吧。总之，现在情况就是这么个情况： LC无药可医，这个不是咱一个人在恶意贩卖焦虑，而是Al-Aly老师等众多顶咖的意思，同时也是Nature编辑们的共识 所以咱下面带货的这堆智商税，完全算不上什么对症良药，也根本不存在什么对症良药。下面的智商税充其量只有还没发表的小规模自筹临床试验这种级别的弱证据而已（图二和图三） 然而，就算只是智商税，也已经是相对而言离谱程度不那么高的智商税了~ 还是那句老话：今后这方面的智商税只会越来越多、越来越夸张、越来越狂野的，各位还请做好思想准备啦~最后，带货传送门见下：O网页链接O网页链接多特倍斯蚓激酶（LC相关）O网页链接O网页链接O网页链接MitoQ 辅酶Q10(LC相关)Swisse斯维诗硫辛酸（LC相关） O网页链接O网页链接（POTS专用）【#什么都可以共存# 】
LC的二三事超话“Long covid＆Cancer”“长新冠＆癌症” L林步里的微博视频

【“参天之木，必有其根；怀山之水，必有其源”如何翻译？】尊敬的安瓦尔总理，各位来宾，女士们、先生们、朋友们：Your Honorable Prime Minister Dato’ Seri Anwar Ibrahim,Distinguished Guests,Ladies and Gentlemen,Friends,大家好！今天我们欢聚一堂，隆重庆祝中国同马来西亚建交50周年暨“中马友好年”。我谨代表中国政府和人民，向马来西亚人民致以诚挚问候和良好祝愿，向长期致力于中马友好的各界人士表示衷心感谢！Good evening! It’s such a pleasure to join all of you tonight to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the establishment of China-Malaysia diplomatic relations, and the Year of China-Malaysia Friendship. On behalf of the Chinese government and people, I would like to extend heartfelt greetings and best wishes to the people of Malaysia, and sincere appreciation to friends from across the society who have long been committed to the friendship between China and Malaysia.正如习近平主席指出，中国同马来西亚是千年结好的邻居、以心相交的朋友、合作共赢的伙伴。中国人常说，“亲望亲好，邻望邻好”。这次访问看到马来西亚发展蒸蒸日上、人民幸福安康，感到由衷高兴。As President Xi Jinping pointed out, China and Malaysia are neighbors with a millennium-old friendship, friends connected by heart, and partners for win-win cooperation. We the Chinese believe that “good neighbors wish each other well.” So when I see, during my visit, your beautiful country making rapid progress and your people living a life of happiness and prosperity, I am truly heartened.回顾中马建交的50年，两国一直是友好往来、真诚相待的好邻居、好朋友、好伙伴。“参天之木，必有其根；怀山之水，必有其源”。50年中马关系发展历程，积累了许多重要的经验启示，也成为我们共同的宝贵财富。Over the past 50 years of diplomatic ties, China and Malaysia have all along treated each other with kindness and sincerity, and remained good neighbors, good friends and good partners. As a Chinese saying goes, “towering trees have deep roots, rolling rivers have abundant sources.” The development of this relationship in the past five decades offers us many important experience and inspirations. They are our shared valuable assets.一是坚持战略自主。50年前，马来西亚顶住冷战压力与中国建交，开中国－东盟关系之先河。过去半个世纪，中马关系一路破浪前行，不为风雨所动，不为外力所扰，两国坚定支持彼此探索符合本国国情的发展道路，为本地区国家关系树立了典范。The first is commitment to independence of strategies. Fifty years ago, Malaysia withstood the pressure of the Cold War and entered into diplomatic relations with China, taking the lead among ASEAN countries. Over the following half a century, China-Malaysia relations have braved the waves and grown stronger, undisturbed by wind and rain, and never interrupted by external forces. Our two countries have rendered each other firm support in exploring the development paths suited to our national conditions. Ours is a fine example of relations between the countries in the region.二是坚持合作共赢。中国连续15年是马来西亚最大贸易伙伴，马来西亚榴莲、山竹等特色水果在中国成为“网红”商品。中马两国在互利互惠中共同发展，经贸往来不断加深，为加快两国各自的现代化进程注入强劲动力。The second is commitment to win-win cooperation. China has been Malaysia’s largest trading partner for 15 consecutive years. Fruits from Malaysia like durian and mangosteen are now quite trending among Chinese consumers. Through mutually beneficial cooperation, our two countries have both achieved growth and built ever closer economic ties, which have created strong impetus for our respective modernization drive.三是坚持守望相助。中马都有句俗语“有福同享，有难同当”。从亚洲金融危机、印度洋海啸、汶川地震到全球新冠疫情，中马两国始终同舟共济，在相互驰援中不断增进理解和信任。The third is commitment to mutual support. “To share weal and woe” is a proverb widely used in both China and Malaysia. From the Asian financial crisis, the Indian Ocean tsunami and the Wenchuan earthquake to the COVID-19 pandemic, China and Malaysia have stood together in times of adversity, come to each other’s assistance, and increased understanding and trust.四是坚持人文相亲。600多年前郑和七下西洋、五次驻节马六甲，播撒和平与友谊的种子。儒家文化和伊斯兰文化在马来西亚交融互促、交相辉映。中马人员往来日益密切，现在中国是马来西亚最大游客来源国之一，两国人民真心对彼此好，双方越走越近、越走越亲。And the fourth is commitment to cultural affinity. Over six hundred years ago, Chinese navigator Zheng He visited Malacca five times during his seven outbound voyages, sowing the seed of peace and friendship. The Confucian culture and the Islamic culture coexist in Malaysia, inspiring and enriching each other. People-to-people exchanges between our two countries are growing stronger, with China becoming one of Malaysia’s largest sources of tourists. We treat each other with sincerity, and this has brought us even closer.今年是“中马友好年”，这一主题年的设立很有意义。“友好”二字重千斤，在当今时代尤为珍贵。当前国际形势变乱交织，一些国家和地区陷入战火和动荡之中，多少平民流离失所、无家可归。可以说，我们所处的世界，缺的是和平安宁、而不是纷争冲突，缺的是理性平和、而不是蛮横暴戾，缺的是将心比心、而不是自我中心，缺的是开放合作、而不是封锁对抗。凡此种种的不友好，动不动相互之间就交恶、交手甚至交战，原因有很多，但归结起来，无非是两个方面：一是客观上的利益问题。特别是面对世界经济增长乏力的困境，如果只讲本国利益，不顾他国发展，必然使资源更加紧张、角逐更加激烈，争夺和矛盾就会越来越多。二是主观上的认知问题。诸如不尊重民族、文化、发展道路的差异，不尊重彼此核心利益，不顾忌人类文明底线等等，都会加剧人类社会的隔阂和冲突。对此应该怎么办？我想关键也是两条：其一，利益上，要更加注重互利共赢的合作，彻底摒弃零和博弈的思维和做法。其二，认知上，要更加注重设身处地的理解，用中国古人的话讲就是“己所不欲，勿施于人”。今年中马开展友好年活动，我认为不仅是为了促进双边关系的更好发展，而且是要以我们的行动来弘扬一种友好的精神，呼吁和感召这个世界上更多的人同心济沧海，携手向未来。To name 2024 the Year of China-Malaysia Friendship is of special significance. “Friendship” is a word that carries great weight, something especially precious today. In a world fraught with changes and turbulence, some countries and regions have been plunged into wars and chaos, and countless civilians displaced and rendered homeless. It’s sad to admit that this is a world that lacks peace and tranquility, but never disputes and conflicts; a world that lacks rationality and humility, but never arbitrary and brutal acts; a world that lacks empathy, but never egocentrism; and a world that lacks openness and cooperation, but never blockade and confrontation. There might be many reasons behind all these hostilities, all these bad feelings that could easily escalate into conflicts and even wars, but they can all boil down to two things: First, objective interests. If a country only has its own interests in mind and gives no regard to the development of others, especially when facing such a sluggish global economy, resources will be further strained, competition will be fiercer, and tussles and conflicts will increase. Second, subjective perception. Showing no respect for the differences between nations, cultures, and development paths, disregarding other’s core interests, and ignoring the bottom line of human conscience... Acts such as these will only aggravate the estrangement and conflicts in our society. What should be done then? I think two things are key here. First, in terms of interests, we should put more emphasis on mutually beneficial and win-win cooperation, and completely discard the zero-sum game thinking and practices. Second, in terms of perception, we should try harder to stand in others’ shoes. This could be best described by the words of wisdom from ancient China: “Do not do to others what you don’t want others to do to you.” I believe our celebrations for the Year of China-Malaysia Friendship is not only designed to grow our bilateral relations, but also to champion the spirit of friendship through our actions, and to call on and rally more from across the world to join hands and cross over to a better, shared future.

双语丨中国翻译协会第40届中译法研讨会成果发布（一）一、时政1.新质生产力 forces productives de nouvelle qualité2.中国人民解放军信息支援部队Force d’appui informatique de l’APL3.国家消防救援局Administration nationale des Incendies et des Secours4.新冠疫情防控实现平稳转段。La lutte contre l’épidémie de COVID-19 est passée en douceur dans une nouvelle phase.5.“四下基层”制度（“四下基层”制度是指：宣传党的路线、方针、政策下基层，调查研究下基层，信访接待下基层，现场办公下基层）système du « quadruple impératif orienté vers la base » (concrètement, la sensibilisation sur la ligne, le programme et la politique du Parti, la conduite d’enquêtes et de recherches, le traitement des plaintes ainsi que le traitement des problèmes sur place doivent tous être orientés vers la base)6.坚持稳中求进、以进促稳、先立后破s’attacher résolument à promouvoir le progrès dans la stabilité et pour la stabilité, et à ne détruire l’ancien que lorsque le nouveau est prêt / à construire le nouveau avant de détruire l’ancien7.提高“一老一小”个人所得税专项附加扣除标准augmenter les déductions spéciales supplémentaires / additionnelles sur l’impôt sur le revenu des personnes physiques (IRPP) pour la prise en charge des descendants et des ascendants / des enfants et des parents8.采取更多惠民生、暖民心举措prendre davantage de mesures bénéfiques au bien-être de la population et appréciées par elle9.“千村示范、万村整治”工程（“千万工程”）Programme de revitalisation rurale verte avec « 1 000 villages phares et 10 000 villages réaménagés »10.大农业观vision globale de l’agriculture11.大食物观vision globale de l’alimentation12.高水平人才高地centre / pôle de talents hautement compétents13.对外开放新高地nouveau pôle d’ouverture à l’extérieur14.绿色低碳发展高地zone modèle / pôle de développement vert et bas carbone15.开辟量子技术、生命科学等新赛道créer de nouveaux axes de développement comme dans les technologies quantiques et les sciences de la vie16.基础教育扩优提质行动action visant à améliorer globalement la qualité de l’enseignement primaire et secondaire17.培育创新文化，弘扬科学家精神，涵养优良学风valoriser / encourager la culture de l’innovation, mettre à l’honneur / faire rayonner l’esprit scientifique, et entretenir l’intégrité académique / encourager les chercheurs à suivre des méthodes de travail irréprochables18.防止顾此失彼、相互掣肘éviter de se focaliser sur une seule mesure ou de mettre en œuvre des mesures contradictoires / incompatibles / qui se contredisent // se garder de trop insister sur un volet en délaissant les autres ou de prendre des mesures qui se contredisent19.（研究储备政策要增强前瞻性、）丰富工具箱，并留出冗余度，确保一旦需要就能及时推出、有效发挥作用。Notre boîte à outils pour l’avenir devra contenir diverses mesures prévisionnelles en nombre plus que suffisant / avec une marge de manœuvre / avec des politiques adaptées à tous les scénarios afin que nous puissions réagir rapidement et efficacement dès que le besoin s’en fera sentir.20.补齐短板、拉长长板、锻造新板，增强产业链供应链韧性和竞争力remédier aux faiblesses / combler les failles des chaînes industrielles et d’approvisionnement, tout en consolidant leurs points forts et en leur donnant des forces nouvelles / en créant des filières nouvelles, de manière à améliorer leur résilience et leur compétitivité21.加强标准引领和质量支撑，打造更多有国际影响力的“中国制造”品牌renforcer le rôle des normes et améliorer la qualité des produits, afin de donner à davantage de marques « fabriqué en Chine » / chinoises un rayonnement mondial / créer davantage de marques chinoises de renom international22.进一步拆除各种藩篱，在更多领域让民间投资进得来、能发展、有作为。Les restrictions seront supprimées dans davantage de secteurs, pour que l’investissement privé puisse y jouer un rôle actif et prospérer. // intensifier les efforts visant à supprimer / éliminer les diverses barrières pour favoriser l’accès, le développement et la réussite des investissements privés dans davantage de secteurs23.勇于打破思维定势和路径依赖，积极谋划用好牵引性、撬动性强的工作抓手，在抓落实上切实做到不折不扣、雷厉风行、求真务实、敢作善为oser rompre avec les idées reçues et les sentiers battus, préparer activement et bien utiliser les leviers dotés d’une forte capacité d’entraînement et d’orientation dans le travail, assurer effectivement une mise en œuvre intégrale et efficace des politiques, dans un esprit pragmatique et soucieux de la vérité, et avec courage et compétence24.以推进“高效办成一件事”为牵引，提高政务服务水平améliorer les services administratifs en promouvant l’idée de « régler les problèmes avec une haute efficacité »25.落实“三个区分开来”，完善干部担当作为激励和保护机制。（“三个区分开来”是指：要把干部在推进改革中因缺乏经验、先行先试出现的失误和错误，同明知故犯的违纪违法行为区分开来；把上级尚无明确限制的探索性试验中的失误和错误，同上级明令禁止后依然我行我素的违纪违法行为区分开来；把为推动发展的无意过失，同为谋取私利的违纪违法行为区分开来。）Tout en perfectionnant le dispositif d’encouragement et de protection des cadres qui remplissent leur devoir avec dévouement, il importe de bien faire / opérer la triple distinction entre les fautes de cadres commises par inexpérience, par imprudence ou par inconscience et celles commises délibérément, par désobéissance ou dans un but de profit personnel. // Trois distinctions : il importe de distinguer les fautes de cadres commises par inexpérience, par imprudence ou par inconscience des fautes commises délibérément, par désobéissance ou dans un but de profit personnel, de manière à perfectionner le mécanisme visant à encourager et protéger les cadres qui font leur devoir, et qui le font bien.26.广大干部要增强“时时放心不下”的责任感，并切实转化为“事事心中有底”的行动力，提振干事创业的精气神，真抓实干、埋头苦干、善作善成，努力创造无愧于时代和人民的新业绩。Les cadres doivent constamment renforcer leur conscience des responsabilités, être sur la brèche jour et nuit et connaître à fond tous leurs dossiers. Ils doivent faire preuve d’initiative dans leur travail, déployer des efforts réels et solides, savoir mener à bien toutes les tâches et accomplir des exploits dignes du peuple et de notre époque.27.两岸同胞都是中国人，没有什么心结不能化解。Les habitants des deux rives du détroit de Taiwan sont tous Chinois, compatriotes au sein de la nation chinoise, il n’y a donc pas de nœuds impossibles à dénouer.28.两岸同胞一路走来，始终一脉相承、心手相连、守望相助。Les habitants des deux rives du détroit de Taiwan, issus de la même lignée, ont toujours agi en solidarité, et se sont entraidés dans l’adversité tout au long de l’histoire / et font preuve de solidarité et d’entraide depuis toujours.29.利莫大于治，害莫大于乱。Rien n’est plus bénéfique que la stabilité, et rien n’est plus préjudiciable que le chaos. // L’ordre est le bien suprême, et le désordre, le mal extrême. // La stabilité est le plus grand bien, et le chaos, le plus grand mal. // Il n’est plus grand bien que la stabilité, rien n’est pire / il n’est plus grand mal que le chaos.

新冠后遗症随着我们进入后疫情时代，越来越多的证据表明，许多感染新冠病毒的人在康复后可能会出现延迟或慢性发病，这被称为新冠急性后遗症（PASC），也被称为长期新冠（Long COVID）。韩国庆熙大学的一项研究发现，在感染新冠病毒后，患过敏性疾病的可能性也会增加。这项研究调用了韩国、日本和英国的跨国数据库，对2200万参与者组成的跨种族队列进行了分析。研究结果显示，感染新型冠状病毒的人比未感染者出现过敏性疾病的风险增加了20%。感染者后续患哮喘的风险增加125%，患过敏性鼻炎的风险增加25%。而且，无论感染的是新冠病毒原始株还是德尔塔变异株，患过敏性疾病的风险都会增加。

#自然简报# 【捣乱抗体可能导致长新冠】当把长新冠患者身上的抗体注射到健康小鼠体内时，小鼠似乎会感觉到疲劳和疼痛——而这正是长新冠的两个特征。这一发现来自两项研究，表明抗体是导致长新冠症状的原因。科学家尚不清楚这一过程是如何运作的，上述结论也需要在更大规模的研究中重复。不过这些结论至少可以帮助克服“决策疲劳”，为长新冠研究的小型动物模型开发提供资金。（参考文献：bioRxiv预印本（未经同行评议））《自然》新闻：What causes long COVID? Case builds for rogue antibodies O网页链接把从长新冠病人身上提取的IgG抗体（艺术渲染图）注射到小鼠体内，小鼠会出现疼痛敏感性增加和运动功能下降等症状。来源：Kateryna Kon/Science Photo Library

把Setting the Record Straight—Does SARS-CoV-2 Cause Type 1 Diabetes? 这个辩论包括双方的rebuttal听完了。正方的观点之前发过了，就是直接讲SARS2感染b细胞的事，展示了包括他自己的研究成果。微博正文由于反方其实不正面反对正方而是在文本结论里认为这件事有不确定性，所以整个辩论非常mild，没有辩起来（双方也认识到了这点）。甚至反方本身因为她是临床医生，所以还强调了“即便在现在许多人把新冠当作cold（原话就是说的cold）来对待，但是我们还是有许多患者在不断的感染和患上long covid，所以我们在这个领域依然需要研究，但我认为这个研究的难度是在不断增长的”。她主要强调的是现在收集数据的缺乏（比如检测缺乏，在糖尿病领域一些研究在文本中不太区分1型和2型，指出后面这点是因为这次的大题是希望针对性的讲讲新冠导致1型的问题），同时她也肯定了著名的老兵研究，认为是非常好的研究（正方在表达观点的时候引用了老兵研究）。正方在rebuttal阶段因为没有什么好辩的，就讲了一些细胞研究方面的点子和其他渠道，并且称这个方面基础研究领域还是蛮amazing的（对研究amazing，对病人不太amazing）。他也讲到同意反方观点，现在病例收集的不完善和有难度，比如基层医疗机构根本不测，那就没办法系统性的收集到有效数据。同时他自己也有提出基础研究方面还是希望可以继续收集更多不同感染背景的患者样本。

确实挺受益匪浅的 复盘一下简单梳理下 aging不能浅层理解由于“僵尸细胞”的存在从而吸引免疫细胞对抗 维持生命的正常代谢 保持一个年轻状态 而aging 正是因为细胞活性的降低 导致身体的炎症加重 从而引发各种疾病 由covid来举例 所谓的“long covid” 感觉身体虚弱容易生病 正是这一道理理论上讲70岁前 是否快速aging由于生活环境精神压力导致 70随后aging或者更多疾病与家族基因关联会更大尽力的保持好状态好心情 开心快乐每一天 努力做一个情绪稳定的主人 又抽象了笑死

content: 啧啧啧，刚刚发现，咱这边一个多月之前已经贩卖过的焦虑，《Science》直到上周才开始卖，是不是咱一不小心又抢跑了？总之，图一是《Science》版本，标题翻译成人话：“LC患者体内的抗体导致小鼠出现症状”看到这熟悉的标题，各位是不是记起来啦？没错当初咱发的就是这一篇：O[含焦量10.0] Putrino老师：“如果你不相信LC，就来一针吧”微博这边的版本则请见：微博正文不过呢，有一说一，《Science》这种段位的媒体亲自贩焦，还是有一定优势的，那就是，有一些虎狼之词，咱这边可能需要遮遮掩掩地委婉表达，而《Science》则可以正大光明地借着专家的嘴巴直接说出来就比如图一和图二的划红线部分吧……又是“dysfunctional immune system”（出岔子的免疫系统），又是“immune-mediated disorder”（免疫系统介导的疾病）这种虎狼之词，他们居然直截了当地就说出口了！当真是不怕烫嘴的咯？【#好日子在后头呢# 】

content: //@聚丙烯酰胺HPAM:long covid，长新冠，新冠后遗症。//@爱吃鱼的唐七七:lc是啥意思诶（没文化的问一下）转发原文：前几天跟一位久居英国刚回国的老先生聊天。他在感叹现在英国有工作意愿的人“充分就业”。因为LC导致大量人口退出就业市场沦为三和大神，空出来的工作岗位就显得充裕...相比之下，国人真就是吃苦耐劳，严重多的LC后遗症却绝大多数都在岗位上坚持或者继续找工作，毕业生就业可不就难看了么再看   展开c

content: 2024年6月12日，The Guardian（卫报）的长新冠专题版面发布了一篇文章：Childhood, interrupted: 12-year-old Toby’s life with long Covid—被打断的童年：12岁的Toby与长新冠的生活。以下是大致内容：英格兰和苏格兰有超过11万名儿童出现了长新冠（long COVID），对Toby来说，这代表着痛苦、极度疲劳和悲伤，还有数月的缺课。我们和Toby的妈妈Sarah、爸爸Simon坐在他们伦敦东部的家中，花园美轮美奂，自从去年放弃工作照顾Toby后，Simon把更多时间花在了园艺上，家中有一个充气泳池，因为他们发现冷水疗法对Toby有益。Toby有一个姐姐，15岁的Isabel，她也出现了长新冠，现在大概康复了85%。Toby已经很久不能去上课了，最近两周他在午餐时间去过课堂，他说见到人的感觉太棒了。Toby于2022年1月感染了新冠，此后一直不适，他的症状包括疼痛、极度疲劳、自主神经异常（体位性心动过速），通常无法行走超过50米或长时间站立，他现在依靠轮椅活动。最糟糕的是运动后不适（PEM），所有他能进行的活动，无论是身体还是精神，都会让他在未来几天或更长时间内筋疲力尽。Toby之后被转诊到一家NHS（英国医疗体系）的长新冠诊所，“那的人说他会好起来的，可能需要几个月时间，但现在再也没有人这么说了，”Sarah告诉我们。ONS（英国统计局）4月公布的最新调查显示，截至3月7日，英格兰和苏格兰有111816名儿童（3-17岁）出现了长新冠，其中有2万多名儿童的日常活动能力受到了很大限制。Binita Kane博士是曼彻斯特的呼吸科医生，她也是一位长新冠医生，以及一名长新冠女孩的母亲。她表示，成年人和儿童的长新冠相似，主要区别在于其对神经系统的影响。因为孩子的大脑正在发育，所以他们的脑部症状往往有点不同，但除此之外共性多于差异。目前还不知道长新冠会持续多久，她确实看到很多家庭有不止一个人受到了影响。Toby去年进步很大，但他在秋季再次感染了新冠，Siomon称，Toby一直是一个善于交际的孩子，他以前很容易交到朋友。他们本来很担心Toby的教育问题，但随着时间的推移，他们发现孩子的健康更重要。除了教育以外，Toby错过了所有的事情——和朋友上学，放学后的活动，游戏和玩伴，生日派对等，他基本错过了整个童年。长新冠影响了他们家庭生活的方方面面，Simon放弃了工作来照顾Toby，因此他自己的心理健康受到了影响。他开始变得焦虑，无法集中注意力，每天难过的抱着儿子。他们也很幸运，因为经济状况尚可，Simon停止工作后，他们为儿子申请了儿童残疾生活津贴，Sarah在伦敦的金融服务公司有一份高薪工作。他们也有能力负担私人医疗，这意味着他们至少能获得更好的康复机会。Isabel和Toby都接受了Kane博士和儿科专家的治疗，Isabel在接受血液稀释药物治疗后取得了改善。专家认为，新冠感染后产生的微血栓会阻止氧气在体内流动，这可能是长新冠的原因之一，包括严重疲劳和疼痛。从医生和长新冠患者母亲的角度来看，Kane应该对长新冠有丰富的经验，但即便拥有很多相关人脉，她仍然无法得到女儿所需的帮助。她说，英格兰和苏格兰有200万人有长新冠，这给医疗服务带来了巨大挑战。NHS并没有跟上新冠至今为止的发展，NHS也无法迅速改变现状，所以目前的情况是脱节且缓慢的，患者应该得到持续的帮助和康复。Toby至今仍然没取得任何显著的进步，他们一家人需要的不是同情，而是改变。“大流行发展到现在，似乎没有人关注长新冠的发病率，为什么我们的孩子和其他受影响的人都不重要？”Long Covid Kids慈善机构一直在帮助这个家庭，他们倡导认识、理解和行动，将正在经历长新冠的人联系起来。学校和卫生机构不鼓励进行新冠检测，甚至建议学生和教职人员感觉没事就可以来学校，但再感染新冠对Toby来说却是相当灾难性的。#新冠##长新冠##新冠肺炎##新冠病毒##新冠病毒感染与认知功能下降存在相关性##新冠后遗症##又一种新冠新毒株突袭多国##关注新冠肺炎##新冠康复日记##新冠肺炎还会与人类共存很长时间##台湾新冠重症及死亡病例大增#

Britain is not broken. It has a historical glory and an ongoing charm as a nation. It is ageing but not weak. Its cornerstones are never lost. Those who wish to serve Britain as leaders need to be real politicians.This nation needs politicians who are not obsessed with radical impulses but are able to initiate and operate pragmatic solutions to solve the most difficult problems, both at home and over the seas. On July the 4th, I’m going to vote for Labour, though they’re actually not competent enough either. But one thing seems quite clear now: KS is plain but not hysterical. After all the pre- and post-Covid political drama - the low competence and high rotation, this country doesn’t need another set of theatrical leaders. It needs a period of stability, with a focus on economic growths rather than wading through ideological trends (How ridiculous it is for political leaders to be endorsed or crushed by ‘men with d**ks but want to call themselves women should be acknowledged as women’ types of ideological void?).  With economic growths as the clear focus, all the tricky and tough things should be addressed firmly but strategically, and kept low-key in public-facing narratives. Ludicrous headline squeaks cannot solve any real problems. With this clear focus on economic growths, hopefully Labour under KS’s light leadership can serve a few years as a barely functioning central-left government. And then they can hand the power over to a new group of politicians who have updated sensibilities, strategies, and energy. This new energy has to derive from Britain’s long-existing old ‘moderate conservative’ values. Based on the moderate conservative values, this nation has thrived across hundreds of years in history, and has earned its long-lasting success and charm. These values should carry on being implemented in the political domain so to accommodate vibrancy and richness in the cultural and social domains, as well as in business and technologies. These heritage British values are clearly not to be manifested in divisive political propaganda or campaigns based on radical ideological illusions, less should it be degraded into the ‘islandy narrow-mindedness’ or populist short-sight moves. It is also unfair to adopt a hindsight to bombard the Brexit initiative which was based on a reasonable ambition, an ambition to reach out across the oceans beyond the ageing continent. It was a bold move frustrated by both unforeseeable historical conditions( mainly the pandemic) and foreseeable realities (i.e. the vexations from Brussel, and the intrinsic restrictions of a democratic structure -which at most times is good of course). Brexit was an attempt driven by ‘the explorer’ heritage character of this nation, rightly beyond the so-called ‘island mentality’.Honestly speaking, the ‘island mentality’ is not going to work for Britain at current times. Any ‘far-right’ fallacies or ideological illusions to isolate this beautiful country will only venerate her future. After all, globalisation as a phenomenon (not ideological agendas) has penetrated through far too many layers of our societies, one of its most powerful demonstrations can be seen in the fused virtual worlds; it does no good for anyone to simply reject the reality. Under all the complex conditions, any impetuous U-turns back to imagined tribal isolation are not going to work. Especially for a geographically-speaking ‘small’ country.  This is why Reform UK needs time to refine their discourse and grow.Hopefully, while Labour works as a nanny government for a few years, Reform UK or the Tories could build or rebuild their teams, could acquire the abilities of first-class politicians to lead the country to further prosperity and stability. Hopefully Britannia can maintain her irreplaceable charm for another hundreds of years. Her advantages were never related to flinging the fist but to resilience, sophistication, and soft power.

content: 新冠对音乐表演（特别是声乐）、体育、舞蹈类从业人员，非常不友好，Long-covid基本上可以提前结束他们的职业生涯。然鹅很多人一开始毫不在意，直到被新冠反复白嫖N次，然后艺术生涯提前结束，至少是伤筋动骨——你很少听到音乐家们提及此事，是因为被人知道听力损伤、身体机能退化是很丢脸的事转发原文：抱歉，根据作者设置的微博可见时间范围，此微博已不可见。
